awd_abstract_narration:
Pure mathematics is fundamental research -- it cannot be judged by its immediate use: history teaches us that important applications arise unexpectedly, years later. In the spirit of the great David Hilbert, our project is problem-driven. As he said over one hundred years ago, ''As long as a branch of science offers an abundance of problems, so long is it alive. [...] It is by the solution of problems that the investigator tests the temper of his steel; he finds new methods and new outlooks, and gains a wider and freer horizon. [...] A mathematical problem should be difficult in order to entice us, yet not completely inaccessible, lest it mock at our efforts.''
 
In the case of this project, most of the problems to be considered were posed over sixty years ago by Paul Erdos, the greatest problem poser in history, and are related to the distribution of primes and modular arithmetic. In fact, the energy and momentum of this project will be established by a kickoff conference which will bring together outstanding mathematicians who have done dynamic and useful work on some of his most challenging problems. For many decades, the main problems seemed to be out of reach, but a few years ago Hough and Nielsen proved some breakthrough results. Within the scope of this project, in applying methods of combinatorics and probability theory to solve several major problems that have remained, some new mathematical techniques for their solutions could be derived that might then be applicable to many other problems, including those in number theory. This project has the promise to be impactful in a number of ways within and beyond the discipline. For example, the factorization of integers is of great practical importance in cryptography, and reconstruction problems are likely to be of use in biology (e.g., DNA sequencing). The second shortest path problem is related to a proposed diagnostic test for schizophrenia.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project opened with a high-class four-day conference on contemporary combinatorics held on September 12-15, 2019 at the University of Memphis which explored the mathematical tradition of Paul Erdős's extensive relationship with the founding members of the Institute of Combinatorics at the University of Memphis. It brought together outstanding mathematicians who have done recent, innovative work in Combinatorics. This meeting provided mathematicians of all levels and abilities the opportunity to develop an appreciation for and contribute to the dialogue about and solutions to problems tackled and posed by some of the most influential mathematicians of the past several decades. The conference featured:

  • A series of excellent talks by some of the most prolific and powerful researchers in combinatorial mathematics and nearby areas, including including Noga Alon, (Princeton), Paul Balister (Memphis), Jozsef Balog (Urbana-Champaign), Enrico Bombieri (IAS, Princeton), Maria Chudnovsky (Princeton),  Peter Frankl (Tokyo),  Andrew Granville (Montreal),  Hugh Montgomery (Ann Arbor), Robert Morris (IMPA, Rio de Janiero), Carl Pomerance (Dartmouth),  Julian Sahasrabudhe (Cambridge),  Alexander Scott (Oxford), Tadashi Tokieda (Stanford), and Ramarathnam Venketasan (Microsoft).
  • A fascinating general audience lecture entitled "Applying physics to mathematics", delivered by Tadashi Tokieda of Stanford University. Not surprisingly, this talk was also very well received.
  • A poster session where students displayed research and a Student/Young Researcher mini-conference where students presented work and received immediate feedback from both senior researchers and peers.

During the first project year, difficulties produced by Covid travel restrictions and illness among key collaborators limited the productivity of PI Bollobás's efforts to work with other researchers. Nevertheless, during the four-year period of this NSF grant the PI published (or has awaiting publication) sixteen papers in highly respected, refereed journals, including Annals of Mathematics, Inventiones, Algebra and Number Theory, The Journal of the European Mathematics Society, Acta Mathematica Hungarica and the Journal of the London Mathematical Society. Most of these papers were in extremal and probabilistic combinatorics, but some were in pure and applied probability theory, number theory, and the confluence of number theory and computer science.

It is embarrassing to say, but I am convinced that the work of this project was significant. One of the most impressive results proven in this grant period is the solution to a 60+ year old problem on Littlewood polynomials. This proof relied on a number of ingredients, and in particular on combinatorial discrepancy theory.  Furthermore, in "Large sumsets from small subsets” published in the Israel J. Math., a new direction was started in additive combinatorics. Considerable extensions of the Erdős-Heilbronn problem were proven. Versions in the continuous setting were presented and several open problems given. Many other problems arise naturally from these results. On June 21, 2022 there was a conference entitled "Renyi 100" in Budapest, with many excellent speakers at which the PI shared this research in a Plenary Lecture entitled "Large Sumsets from Small Subsets".This project provided opportunities and platforms for ideas to be shared and interactions to be initiated among rising researchers. Many occasions were provided for graduate students learning the art of collaboration.   These experiences provided significant foundation for productive networking, longer term collaborations, and meaningful contribution to dissertations, workshops, classes and seminars. In fact, three students completed their dissertations: 

  1. David Lewis. "Extremal Graph Theory and Dimension Theory for Partial Orders". (2020).  University of Memphis.
  2. Rebekah Herrman. "Walks and Games on Graphs". (2020).  University of Memphis.
  3. Sovanlal Mondal. "Behavior of Ergodic Averages along a Subsequence and the Grid Method". (2023).  University of Memphis.

Furthermore, during the course of this project, the PI gave several short programs to undergraduates and graduates at the Instituto Nacional de Matematica Pura e Aplicada at Rio de Janiero, Brazil (IMPA), which is considered the foremost research and educational institution of Brazil in the area of mathematics.  These programs dealt with problems connected to multiple areas related to this research or techniques used therein. The problems varied in difficulty, but each required real ideas; many of which turned out to be useful in a variety of different settings, and a few had led to the development of entirely new areas of mathematics.  Several senior researchers participated, collaborated with students and gave workshops and seminars.  The PhD students also had opportunities to give mini seminars and receive feedback from peers and senior researchers, and to get much needed experience sharing their research publicly.
